case_name: Pfizer Private Ltd. v. Its Employees

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 625 and 626 of 1962 are appeals by special leave from the award dated June 9, 1962 of the Industrial Tribunal, Maharashtra in Reference IT No 16 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 625 626 of 1962. Appeals by special leave from the award dated June 9, 1962, of the Industrial Tribunal, Maharashtra in Reference  IT  No 16 of 1962.

facts.text: Two items of dispute between Pfizer Private Ltd. and its employees were referred to Industrial Tribunal, Bombay by Government of Maharashtra on January 22, 1962 under sections 10 and 12(5) of Industrial Disputes Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-Two items of dispute between the appellant Pfizer Private Ltd., and the respondents, its employees, were referred for adjudication to the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, by the Government of Maharashtra under ss. 1     1   d  and. 12  5  of the Industrial Disputes Act 1947 on the 22nd of January, 1962.

facts.text: Pfizer proposed to reduce existing paid holidays from 27 to 8.

anchor.surface_text: Both these items arose out of the proposed changes which the appellant wanted to make in the terms of employment governing the service of the respondents. The appellant proposed to reduce the existing paid holidays to 8 instead of 27 to which the respondents were entitled because so long, the appellant has been giving to its employees the benefit of public holidays as declared under the Negotiable Instruments Act.

facts.text: Pfizer desired to introduce three shifts in most departments and gave notice under section 9A of Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: The second item of dispute was in regard to re-fixation of the hours of work. The appellant desired to introduce three shifts in most of its departments and accordingly it had given a numberice of change under s. 9A of the Industrial Disputes Act.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal rejected Pfizer's case for three shifts.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has rejected the appellants case for the introduction of three shifts in its factory and this part of the award is challenged by the appellant by its appeal No. 625 of 1962.

facts.text: Tribunal directed reduction of holidays to 10 per year with consultation and additional increment from August 1, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the appellants claim for reducing the paid holidays, the Tribunal has substantially accepted the appellants case and has directed that, the holidays should be reduced to 10 every year. has directed,the appellant to fix these holidays in companysultation with the respondents. It has also added that in view of the fact that a substantial reduction was being made in the number of paid holidays, the appellant should give the respondents an additional increment in their grade with effect from the 1st August, 1962.

facts.text: Pfizer is a company incorporated under Indian Companies Act, 1913 with registered office at Bombay and factory manufacturing life saving drugs like antibiotics, anti-tubercular drugs, vitamin products.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a Company incorporated under the the Indian Companies Act, 1913. It has its registered office at Bombay and it runs a factory in which it manufactures life saving drugs, such as antibiotics and anti-tubercular drugs, and vitamin products.

facts.text: Pfizer's factory had multiplicity of shifts but underutilized machinery and raw products from Chandigarh factory.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants factory was working a multiplicity of shifts with different times. It, however, found that this working did number fully utilise the machinery installed in the factory. The utilisation of the raw product received by the appellants factory in Bombay from its factory at Chandigarh was also number satisfactory

facts.text: Pfizer developed P.A.S. after lab and pilot experiments in 1960-61 requiring continuous three-shift process.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, the preparation of the well-known anti-tubercular drug Para Amino Salicylic Acid  P.A.S.  which the appellant had developed in its research laboratory after carrying out laboratory and pilot plant experiments in 1960-61, needed the working of the relevant section on a three-shift basis because its production was a companytinuous process

facts.text: Employees resisted three shifts claiming benefit of 5-day week as term of employment.

anchor.surface_text: The demand for three shifts was stoutly resisted by the respondents. They urged, that for several years past, in the appellants factory the respondents have received the benefit of 5-days week and that has number become a term of their employment

facts.text: Tribunal held pharmaceutical factories in Greater Bombay work one or two shifts, rarely three in chemical sections.

anchor.surface_text: It found that the effect of the documentary evidence produced was to show that the pharmaceutical factories in Greater Bombay worked one, and in some cases, two shifts, though in a few cases, there were three shifts only in the section manufacturing chemicals and number pharmaceuticals.

facts.text: Tribunal rejected three shifts for P.A.S. as not requiring continuous process.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the appellants claim that the production of P.A. S. involved a companytinuous process, the Tribunal observed that the evidence produced by the appellant did number show that in the present state of manufacture by it of P. A. S. it would be companyvenient to have three shifts

facts.text: Pfizer factory employs 821 workmen, 235 girl employees.

anchor.surface_text: The factory of the appellant employs 821. workmen, 235 of whom are girl employees and since s. 66 1  b  of the Factories Act prohibits the employment of women in any factory, except between the hours of 6 A.M. and 7 P.M.

facts.text: Current working: Department 1 (P.A.S. etc.) 6-day week, three shifts, 125 employees.

anchor.surface_text: The statement filed by the appellant  Exb.C-1  shows that there are four departments in the appellants factory. The first department which Works 6-day week on a three shift basis deals with P.A.S. Watch and Ward, Maintenance and Hydrazine. [...] The total number of employees in this department is 125.

facts.text: Proposed three shifts would change to 6-day week, increase working hours by 1-1/4 hours, net 55 minutes per week.

anchor.surface_text: The result of the introduction of the 3 shifts would be,, the working hours will increase by 1-1/4, the net increase in the working timings being 55 minutes per week.

facts.text: National emergency requires increased industrial production.

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with the merits of the dispute in the present appeals, it is essential to bear in mind that in the face of the present national emergency, the companyplexion of the problem has companypletely changed.

facts.text: Dr. Joshi testified P.A.S. production rejection 65% in January 1962 due to M.A.P., requires continuous 20-hour process post-purification needing three shifts.

anchor.surface_text: In his affidavit he stated that the P.A.S. was put on companymercial production basis in January, 1962, and be found by experience that out of the total January production of 2770 Kg. as much as 1795. g., i.e. 65, was rejected. [...] three shifts are inevitable.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds P.A.S. production is continuous process requiring three shifts.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, there can be numberdoubt Whatever that the appellant is entitled to start 3 shifts in the P.A.S. section and produce P.A.S. in larger quantities and of a better quality.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows introduction of three shifts subject to Tribunal deciding additional payment.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore, satisfied that the Tribunal was in error in rejecting the appellants case for the introduction of 3 shifts.

facts.text: Supreme Court reduces paid holidays to 16 per year instead of 27 under Negotiable Instruments Act.

anchor.surface_text: Having companysidered all the relevant facts in the present case, we are disposed to think that the number of public holidays which are granted by the appellant to the respondents should be reduced from those sanctioned under the Negotiable Instruments Act to 16 every year.

facts.text: Pfizer gives employees all 27 public holidays under Negotiable Instruments Act.

anchor.surface_text: We have already seen that the appellant gives to its employees all the public holidays under the Negotiable Instruments Act. In the relevant year, the number of such public holidays was 27.

facts.text: Interim arrangement allowed three shifts in P.A.S. department with rotation of two employees paid 10% extra.

anchor.surface_text: Under this arrangement, the appellant was authorised to introduce a third shift in that department and rotate up to two employees number engaged in the other shifts in the night shift. [...] paid 10 over their basic wages

issues.text: Whether the appellant is entitled to introduce three shifts in its factory by notice under s.9A of the Industrial Disputes Act

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-Two items of dispute between the appellant Pfizer Private Ltd., and the respondents, its employees, were referred for adjudication to the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, by the Government of Maharashtra under ss. 1     1   d  and. 12  5  of the Industrial Disputes Act 1947 on the 22nd of January, 1962.

issues.text: Whether the number of paid holidays should be reduced from 27 to 8 and if the reduction is justified

anchor.surface_text: Both these items arose out of the proposed changes which the appellant wanted to make in the terms of employment governing the service of the respondents. The appellant proposed to reduce the existing paid holidays to 8 instead of 27 to which the respondents were entitled because so long, the appellant has been giving to its employees the benefit of public holidays as declared under the Negotiable Instruments Act.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal was right in holding that the production of P.A.S. does not involve a continuous process requiring three shifts

anchor.surface_text: Let us then consider whether the Tribunal was right in holding that the production of P.A.S. does not involve a continuous process. On this point, the appellant led the evidence of Dr. Joshi who is M.Sc. Ph.D. in Organic Chemistry of the Bombay University.

anchor.surface_text: The main argument on which Mr. Sule has relied and which has found favour with the Tribunal is based on the pattern of industrial employment in pharmaceutical industry in the region of Bombay. We would, therefore, very briefly, refer to this pattern.

arguments.claim: Introduction of three shifts is necessary to fully utilize machinery, improve raw material utilization, meet market demand, enable exports, and compete effectively

anchor.surface_text: The appellants factory was working a multiplicity of shifts with different times. It, however, found that this working did number fully utilise the machinery installed in the factory. The utilisation of the raw product received by the appellants factory in Bombay from its factory at Chandigarh was also number satisfactory and as a result of inadequate production, the appellant was riot able to meet adequately the demand for its products from the market. That is why the appellant came to the companyclusion that there was need to introduce three shifts in order to have extensive production of better quality products.

holdings.text: The Tribunal was in error in holding that the production of P.A.S. does not involve a continuous process requiring three shifts; the appellant is entitled to start 3 shifts in the P.A.S. section.

anchor.surface_text: Let us then consider whether the Tribunal was right in holding that the production of P.A.S. does not involve a continuous process. On this point, the appellant led the evidence of Dr. Joshi who is M.Sc. Ph.D. in Organic Chemistry of the Bombay University. [...] Therefore, there can be nodoubt Whatever that the appellant is entitled to start 3 shifts in the P.A.S. section and produce P.A.S. in larger quantities and of a better quality.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preferred technical evidence of Dr. Joshi (expert, supported by records) over non-technical Pillai and Tribunal's assessment; process post-purification takes 20 hours requiring continuity.

holdings.text: The Tribunal was in error in rejecting the appellant's case for the introduction of 3 shifts; appellant entitled to introduce three shifts subject to Tribunal deciding additional payment.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore, satisfied that the Tribunal was in error in rejecting the appellants case for the introduction of 3 shifts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: National emergency prioritizes production; evidence shows underutilization, P.A.S. needs, chemical sections use 3 shifts; standing orders permit subject to reasonableness; remit payment issue.

holdings.text: Number of paid holidays should be reduced from 27 under Negotiable Instruments Act to 16 per year.

anchor.surface_text: Having considered all the relevant facts in the present case, we are disposed to think that the number of public holidays which are granted by the appellant to the respondents should be reduced from those sanctioned under the Negotiable Instruments Act to 16 every year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: NI Act holidays apply mainly to govt institutions, not binding on factories; too many holidays hinder production needs in emergency; compared state govt policies (14-18); Tribunal's 10 too low given 3 shifts allowed.

holdings.text: Standing Orders constitute statutory terms and conditions allowing management discretion for multiple shifts, but if disputed and referred, Tribunal must consider reasonableness of proposed change.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Standing Orders under 1946 Act are statutory; s.9A notice triggers scrutiny for changes in conditions despite standing orders; not absolute discretion nor prohibited by pattern.

holdings.text: Industry pattern in pharmaceutical sector does not rigidly prohibit introduction of three shifts, especially in chemical sections and overridden by national production needs.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, on the material placed before us, it is clear that the chemical sections of the pharmaceutical factories do, work 3 shifts and this would have a direct bearing on the appellants case in regard to the P.A.S. section of its factory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows 3 shifts in chemical sections of several factories; pattern not binding doctrine, especially in emergency requiring higher production; Tribunal's rigid regional view erroneous.

holdings.text: Holidays under Negotiable Instruments Act not binding on factories or commercial establishments.

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with the question of paid holidays, it may be relevant to remember that the holidays declared under the Negotiable Instruments Act are usually applicable to Government institutions only and they have certain financial and statutory implications envisaged by the Act itself. The commercial establishments and factories do not usually adopt these holidays.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual/purposive: Act targets govt institutions with specific implications; factories not required to follow; supports reduction for production.

holdings.text: Case remitted to Tribunal to decide additional payment/compensation for employees consequent to introduction of three shifts.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellate court cannot decide payment quantum; employer willing; interim continues till decision.

holdings.text: In national emergency, industrial adjudication must prioritize increased production over doctrinaire views on 5-day week, night work, or industry pattern.

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with the merits of the dispute in the present appeals, it is essential to bear in mind that in the face of the present national emergency, the complexion of the problem has completely changed... all legitimate efforts made by the employer to produce more and more of the goods required for the community must receive the cooperation of the employees-of course, on reasonable terms.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicial notice of emergency alters approach; production paramount; balance with reasonable compensation.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: The result is, both the appeals are allowed. Appeal No. 625 of 1962 succeeds and the change proposed to be made by the appellant according to the numberice of change served by it on the respondents is allowed to be made, subject to the decision of the Tribunal on the

outcome.relief_summary: Both appeals allowed; employer's appeal succeeds permitting introduction of three shifts subject to Tribunal deciding additional payment to employees; employees' appeal succeeds by modifying holiday reduction from 10 to 16 per year
